reasoning: [Specific Program Not Verified] Paper mentions 'Nepal Poverty Alleviation Fund (PAF)' but search could not confirm this as graduation program: Perplexity search result: The Nepal Poverty Alleviation Fund (PAF) is a community-driven development program targeting the rural poor to improve their welfare, livelihoods, and empowerment with a focus on marginalized groups[3][5][8]. The PAF provides support through small-scale infrastructure, capacity building, and grants to community organizations primarily for income generation and local infrastructure projects. The main instrument is the provision of productive assets in the form of grants or revolving funds for income-generating activities, often including livestock, seeds, or tools[3][6]. There is no evidence in official evaluations or program documentation indicating regular cash transfers or stipends as a program component[3][5][6][8]. PAF is not termed a 'graduation program' (as the term is commonly used for multi-component interventions leading the ultra-poor to self-sufficiency, often sequenced like BRAC's Graduation Approach), nor is graduation language a core aspect of the program's design in any official documents. Rather, it is a multi-faceted livelihood development initiative. | Graduation: NO, Cash: NO, Assets: YES | Confidence: HIGH | Sources: https://giwmscdntwo.gov.np/media/app/public/56/posts/1684843052_68.pdf, https://ieg.worldbankgroup.org/reports/nepal-poverty-alleviation-fund-project-0, https://if.ad.org/documents/48415603/49457717/Nepal+1100001450+PAF+II+Project+Completion+Report+June+2019.pdf/2295d829-3d6d-5e47-ea2c-dfca4c299aa7?t=1726609137321
